Author: gibsonf1
Content: PG: Do you prefer teams to submit not quite complete forms and then incrementally add info as time goes by, or do you prefer a complete application submitted and then minor updates as time goes by?

Author: danw
Content:
I mentioned this to a friend of mine the other day and she simply said "What ads on facebook?". She not a techie, doesn't use an ad blocker and logs into facebook daily. We're all used to these ads and don't even see them anymore, in much the same way we all channel surf or go to make a cup of tea during TV ad breaks.

Perhaps we need a new way of delivering ads in communication apps that differs from information & entertainment apps. Twitter, facebook, blyk and many other face this same problem with monetisation. Whats the solution? Is it ok to analyse what people are saying to each other and deliver text link ads inline with the conversation. If I say "Want to go for a drink later?" to a friend on facebook should there be a link underneath saying "Get half price drinks a Bob's Bar"?

Any ideas?

Author: myoung8
Content:
I agree, I don't think most of the comparisons out there are apt, other than the fact the two companies are both at the center of IPO speculation in the valley.

Granted I'm still in college, but my Facebook profile and my LinkedIn profile are like night and day. I do put some of the information from LinkedIn on Facebook (they do have a Work & Education section in profiles), but that's not why people look at my profile.

I certainly wouldn't want the comments on my wall showing up when people are analyzing my profile as a job candidate.

The two services just don't mesh very well on a high level.

Title: Facebook delivers appalling ad clickthroughs: 0.04% clickthrough

Content:
I'm curious to hear why you think LinkedIn is broken...

It seems to be working pretty well for a lot of people.
